body.p:
To His Excellency Beriah Magoffin
Govr. of Kentucky
Respected Sir

Your petitioner Richd. Marsh has had his fine respited on the 18th Feby 1860 -- for one year which fine amounted to One Hundred dolls. the costs 30 pr cent Marshalls & Clerks fees &c have since then been paid in addition to the statements set forth in his former petition he says that since that time he has intermarried & in consequence of political excitements business of all Kinds has in a measure stopped & he has been unable to do more than partially provide for his family, he runs the river as a coal boat hand wherever he can & when not there engaged he busies himself as house painter there is nothing doing in either now he is a sober industrious & strives to do what a good citizen ought to do
but is totally unable to pay the remainder of this fine & does not wish to go to the workhouse & entail disgrace upon his family he prays your excellency to remit his fine & he will ever be most grateful

with great respect I am Sir
your obt Servt
Richard Marsh
Sworn to before me this 11th day of March 18601
Patrick Joyes N P J. C
We neighbors & friends of Richd. Marsh pray yr Excellency to remit his fine & we will be much obliged
